page.title: 03SUDBOROUGH CHURCH
page.content: Sudborough Church is a post-Norman, l3th century church. It is relatively large for the size of the village, about l4O inhabitants. It is transeptal in shape and was built on the site of a Saxon church using some of the original stones. Behind the altar lies Sir Robert De Vere, standard bearer to the Earl of Salisbury, who fell in battle against the Saracens on a crusade in 1249. The church seats 100 to 120 and is in the diocese of Peterborough. It houses a magnificent clock which has no face or hands but chimes each quarter. There is also a font made of lead and covered with a carved wooden lid. In the northern transept are two 14th century brass rubbings, depicting a man, his wife and their eleven children.
